Python (Microsoft) Useful links Python Miniconda Documentation Google Colab How to use this repository Below are the steps you need to follow: Create a GitHub account if you don’t have one. Fork this repository to your account. Enable the Issues tab: Go to the Settings tab and check the Issues option. Add your professor as a collaborator: Go to the Settings tab and add their GitHub username in the Collaborators section. docs.title: Where can I find the problems?

docs.text:
Mathematical Formulation of Projectile Motion 1.1 Governing Equations of Motion Using Newton’s Second Law , considering only gravitational force (neglecting air resistance): \[ F = ma = -mg \hat{y} \] This results in two differential equations: Horizontal motion : [  rac{d^2x}{dt^2} = 0 ] Vertical motion : [  rac{d^2y}{dt^2} = -g ] 2. Solving the Equations Given initial conditions: Initial position : \((x_0, y_0) = (0, y_0)\) Initial velocity : \( v_0 \) at an angle \( 	heta \) Velocity components : [ v_{0x} = v_0 \cos	heta, \quad v_{0y} = v_0 \sin	heta ] The general solutions are: \[ x(t) = v_0 \cos	heta \cdot t \] \[ y(t) = y_0 + v_0 \sin	heta \cdot t -  rac{1}{2} g t^2 \] 3. Time of Flight The time of flight is found by solving \( y(t) = 0 \) (when the projectile returns to its initial height \( y_0 \) ). For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ 0 = v_0 \sin	heta \cdot t -  rac{1}{2} g t^2 \] Solving for \( t \) : \[ t =  rac{2 v_0 \sin	heta}{g} \] For \( y_0 
eq 0 \) , solving the quadratic equation \( y(t) = 0 \) : \[ t =  rac{v_0 \sin	heta + \sqrt{(v_0 \sin	heta)^2 + 2g y_0}}{g} \] 4. Range Calculation The horizontal range \( R \) is: For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos	heta \cdot  rac{2 v_0 \sin	heta}{g} =  rac{v_0^2 \sin 2	heta}{g} \] For \( y_0 
eq 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos	heta \cdot t \] where \( t \) is given by the quadratic formula above. 5. Maximum Height The maximum height occurs when vertical velocity becomes zero ( \( v_y = 0 \) ): \[ H =  rac{v_0^2 \sin^2	heta}{2g} \] For \( y_0 
eq 0 \) : \[ H = y_0 +  rac{v_0^2 \sin^2	heta}{2g} \] 6. Optimal Launch Angle The launch angle that maximizes the range for \( y_0 = 0 \) is: \[ 	heta_{	ext{optimal}} = 45^\circ \] For \( y_0 > 0 \) , the optimal angle is slightly less than \( 45^\circ \) , given by: \[ 	heta_{	ext{optimal}} \approx 45^\circ -  rac{y_0}{v_0^2} \cdot k \] where \( k \) is a proportionality constant. These equations provide a complete theoretical framework for projectile motion analysis. Would you like further modifications or additional explanations? 1.2. Theoretical Analysis of Range The range \( R \) of a projectile launched at an angle \( 	heta \) with initial velocity \( v_0 \) is given by: \[ R =  rac{v_0^2 \sin 2	heta}{g} \] where: - \( v_0 \) is the initial velocity, - \( g \) is the gravitational acceleration, - \( 	heta \) is the angle of projection. Key Observations: Dependence on \( 	heta \) : The range is maximized when \( \sin 2	heta \) is maximized, which occurs at \( 	heta = 45^\circ \) . The function is symmetric around \( 45^\circ \) , meaning \( R(	heta) = R(90^\circ - 	heta) \) . Beyond \( 45^\circ \) , increasing \( 	heta \) decreases the horizontal component of velocity, reducing \( R \) . Effect of Initial Velocity \( v_0 \) : Since \( R \propto v_0^2 \) , doubling \( v_0 \) quadruples the range. A higher velocity results in a greater overall displacement. Effect of Gravity \( g \) : Since \( R \propto  rac{1}{g} \) , an increase in gravitational acceleration decreases the range. On planets with lower gravity (e.g., Moon, Mars), projectiles travel farther for the same \( v_0 \) . Effect of Initial Height \( y_0 \) : If the projectile is launched from a height \( y_0 > 0 \) , range is extended due to a longer time of flight. The range equation is modified to account for this additional height: \[ t =  rac{v_0 \sin	heta + \sqrt{(v_0 \sin	heta)^2 + 2gy_0}}{g} \] \[ R = v_0 \cos	heta \cdot t \] 3. Observations from Graphs Effect of Velocity: The peak of the curve shifts upward as \( v_0 \) increases, confirming \( R \propto v_0^2 \) . Effect of Height: When \( y_0 \) increases , the range extends beyond \( 	heta = 45^\circ \) . The maximum range shifts to a slightly lower angle (e.g., \( 40^\circ \) instead of \( 45^\circ \) ). 4. Limitations & Extensions Limitations: Ignores air resistance: In reality, air drag reduces range. No wind effects: Wind can increase/decrease range depending on direction. Flat terrain assumption: Uneven ground alters projectile trajectory. Extensions: Air Resistance Model: [ F_{	ext{drag}} =  rac{1}{2} C_d ho A v^2 ] Implementing numerical methods to model drag forces . Wind Influence: Adding lateral forces for real-world accuracy. 5. Conclusion The range follows a parabolic trend with respect to \( 	heta \) , maximizing at \( 45^\circ \) . Increasing \( v_0 \) quadratically increases range. Higher launch height shifts the optimal angle below \( 45^\circ \) . Gravity acts as an inverse factor , reducing the range when increased. This provides a solid foundation for studying real-world projectile motion, from sports science (basketball, soccer) to aerospace applications (missile trajectory planning). Would you like additional details or modifications? 🚀
docs.title: Problem 1

docs.text: Using Newton’s Second Law , considering only gravitational force (neglecting air resistance): \[ F = ma = -mg \hat{y} \] This results in two differential equations: Horizontal motion : [ \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} = 0 ] Vertical motion : [ \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} = -g ]
docs.title: 1.1 Governing Equations of Motion

docs.text: Given initial conditions: Initial position : \((x_0, y_0) = (0, y_0)\) Initial velocity : \( v_0 \) at an angle \( \theta \) Velocity components : [ v_{0x} = v_0 \cos\theta, \quad v_{0y} = v_0 \sin\theta ] The general solutions are: \[ x(t) = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot t \] \[ y(t) = y_0 + v_0 \sin\theta \cdot t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \]
docs.title: 2. Solving the Equations

docs.text: The time of flight is found by solving \( y(t) = 0 \) (when the projectile returns to its initial height \( y_0 \) ). For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ 0 = v_0 \sin\theta \cdot t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \] Solving for \( t \) : \[ t = \frac{2 v_0 \sin\theta}{g} \] For \( y_0 \neq 0 \) , solving the quadratic equation \( y(t) = 0 \) : \[ t = \frac{v_0 \sin\theta + \sqrt{(v_0 \sin\theta)^2 + 2g y_0}}{g} \]
docs.title: 3. Time of Flight

docs.text: The horizontal range \( R \) is: For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot \frac{2 v_0 \sin\theta}{g} = \frac{v_0^2 \sin 2\theta}{g} \] For \( y_0 \neq 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot t \] where \( t \) is given by the quadratic formula above.
docs.title: 4. Range Calculation

docs.text: The maximum height occurs when vertical velocity becomes zero ( \( v_y = 0 \) ): \[ H = \frac{v_0^2 \sin^2\theta}{2g} \] For \( y_0 \neq 0 \) : \[ H = y_0 + \frac{v_0^2 \sin^2\theta}{2g} \]
docs.title: 5. Maximum Height

docs.text: The launch angle that maximizes the range for \( y_0 = 0 \) is: \[ \theta_{\text{optimal}} = 45^\circ \] For \( y_0 > 0 \) , the optimal angle is slightly less than \( 45^\circ \) , given by: \[ \theta_{\text{optimal}} \approx 45^\circ - \frac{y_0}{v_0^2} \cdot k \] where \( k \) is a proportionality constant. These equations provide a complete theoretical framework for projectile motion analysis. Would you like further modifications or additional explanations?
docs.title: 6. Optimal Launch Angle

docs.text: The range \( R \) of a projectile launched at an angle \( \theta \) with initial velocity \( v_0 \) is given by: \[ R = \frac{v_0^2 \sin 2\theta}{g} \] where: - \( v_0 \) is the initial velocity, - \( g \) is the gravitational acceleration, - \( \theta \) is the angle of projection.
docs.title: 1.2. Theoretical Analysis of Range

docs.text: Dependence on \( \theta \) : The range is maximized when \( \sin 2\theta \) is maximized, which occurs at \( \theta = 45^\circ \) . The function is symmetric around \( 45^\circ \) , meaning \( R(\theta) = R(90^\circ - \theta) \) . Beyond \( 45^\circ \) , increasing \( \theta \) decreases the horizontal component of velocity, reducing \( R \) . Effect of Initial Velocity \( v_0 \) : Since \( R \propto v_0^2 \) , doubling \( v_0 \) quadruples the range. A higher velocity results in a greater overall displacement. Effect of Gravity \( g \) : Since \( R \propto \frac{1}{g} \) , an increase in gravitational acceleration decreases the range. On planets with lower gravity (e.g., Moon, Mars), projectiles travel farther for the same \( v_0 \) . Effect of Initial Height \( y_0 \) : If the projectile is launched from a height \( y_0 > 0 \) , range is extended due to a longer time of flight. The range equation is modified to account for this additional height: \[ t = \frac{v_0 \sin\theta + \sqrt{(v_0 \sin\theta)^2 + 2gy_0}}{g} \] \[ R = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot t \]
docs.title: Key Observations:

docs.text: Effect of Velocity: The peak of the curve shifts upward as \( v_0 \) increases, confirming \( R \propto v_0^2 \) . Effect of Height: When \( y_0 \) increases , the range extends beyond \( \theta = 45^\circ \) . The maximum range shifts to a slightly lower angle (e.g., \( 40^\circ \) instead of \( 45^\circ \) ).
docs.title: 3. Observations from Graphs

docs.text: Ignores air resistance: In reality, air drag reduces range. No wind effects: Wind can increase/decrease range depending on direction. Flat terrain assumption: Uneven ground alters projectile trajectory.
docs.title: Limitations:

docs.text: Air Resistance Model: [ F_{\text{drag}} = \frac{1}{2} C_d \rho A v^2 ] Implementing numerical methods to model drag forces . Wind Influence: Adding lateral forces for real-world accuracy.
docs.title: Extensions:

docs.text: The range follows a parabolic trend with respect to \( \theta \) , maximizing at \( 45^\circ \) . Increasing \( v_0 \) quadratically increases range. Higher launch height shifts the optimal angle below \( 45^\circ \) . Gravity acts as an inverse factor , reducing the range when increased. This provides a solid foundation for studying real-world projectile motion, from sports science (basketball, soccer) to aerospace applications (missile trajectory planning). Would you like additional details or modifications? 🚀
